questions.text: 1. A class is being conducted on the various structures present in the next. Neck dissection is performed, and the given image shows the lateral aspect of the neck. All of the following muscles are supplied by nerves arising from the structure 'A' and its branches, except _____.
questions.solution:
The structure marked as A in the above image is the inferior root of ansa cervicalis, and it supplies all the above-mentioned muscles, except the thyrohyoid.

The inferior root descends on the lateral side of the internal jugular vein, crosses it a little below the middle of the neck, and continues forwards to join the superior root anterior to the common carotid artery, forming the ansa cervicalis (ansa hypoglossi).

Ansa cervicalis: 

* It is a loop of nerves that are a part of the cervical plexus. It is made up of two roots. The upper root has contributions from the first cervical spinal nerve, and the lower root has contributions from the second and third cervical spinal nerves.

* It innervates sternohyoid, sternothyroid, and omohyoid muscles.

The thyrohyoid and geniohyoid are not supplied by ansa cervicalis. They are supplied by the first cervical spinal nerve, via the hypoglossal nerve.

questions.text: 2. All of the following are branches of the structure marked in the image, except _______.
questions.solution:
The marked structure can be identified as the superior mesenteric artery, as it lies anterior and superior to the left renal vein. The left colic artery is a branch of the inferior mesenteric artery, not the superior mesenteric artery.

The superior mesenteric artery originates from the abdominal aorta at the level of the L1 vertebra.

Branches of the superior mesentric artery:

* Jejunal branches

* Ileal branches

* Middle colic artery

* Right colic artery

* Ileocolic artery

* Inferior pancreaticoduodenal artery

Clinical note: Nutcracker syndrome

* It occurs due to left renal vein entrapment, i.e., the compression of the left renal vein between the abdominal aorta and the superior mesenteric artery,

* The compression occurs in the sagittal plane, appearing as if a nutcracker is crushing a nut (the left renal vein).

questions.text:
3. In a practical anatomy exam, the following sulcus is marked (X in the image) and asked for its contents, you would answer:

* Long head of biceps brachii muscle

* Short head of biceps brachii muscle

* Ascending branch from the posterior circumflex humeral artery

* Descending branch from the posterior circumflex humeral artery

* Ascending branch from the anterior circumflex humeral artery
questions.solution:
The marked area is Intertubercular sulcus(bicipital groove) which lies between the greater and lesser tubercles. Its contents are 1 and 5 only.

The attachments of the bicipital groove are as follows:

* Lateral lip: Pectoralis major

* Medial lip: Teres major

* Floor: Latissimus dorsi

The contents of the sulcus are as follows:

* The long head of the biceps and its synovial sheath.

* ascending branch from the anterior circumflex humeral artery.

MEMORY TIP:

Remember 'Lady between two majors': The lady (Latissimsus dorsi), in the intertubercular sulcus, lies between the Pectoralis major laterally, and Teres major medially.

questions.text: 4. The following muscle is marked in the anatomy practical exam, the examiner asks you to provide the origin, insertion, and nerve supply of it. What would your answer be?

choices.text: Origin:  Radius, Insertion: Ulna, Nerve supply: Median nerve
Origin:  Radius, Insertion: Ulna, Nerve supply: Radial nerve
Origin: Ulna, Insertion: Radius, Nerve supply: Median nerve
Origin: Ulna, Insertion: Radius, Nerve supply: Radial nerve

questions.solution:
The marked structure in the image is the pronator quadratus muscle. The answer is origin: Ulna, insertion: Radius, nerve supply: Median nerve. 

The pronator quadratus is a flat quadrilateral-shaped muscle, that extends across the front of the distal ends of the radius and ulna. It arises from the anterior surface of the shaft of the ulna and inserts into the shaft of the radius and the ulnar notch of the radius.

The pronator quadratus is innervated by the median nerve (C7 and 8). It is supplied by the anterior interosseus artery. It causes the pronation of the forearm at the radioulnar joint.

questions.text: 5. During routine dissection classes, you and your friend are discussing the cadaveric specimen of the inferior surface of the liver. Which of the following lobe is referred to as segment I?
questions.solution:
The lobe marked as '3' in the above image represents the caudate lobe which is referred to as segment I.

Couinaud's segmental division of the liver is the functional division based on the portal venous branches in the parenchyma. They are divided into 8 functional segments. The caudate lobe corresponds to segment I of Couinaud's segments.

The caudate lobe of the liver has a portal blood supply and hepatic vein drainage independent of the remainder of the liver and also forms the superior boundary of the epiploic foramen. 

The caudate lobe is visible as prominent on the inferior and posterior surfaces of the liver. It lies posterior to the porta hepatis and to its right is the groove for the inferior vena cava.

Other markings:

1-Quadrate lobe

2-Right lobe

4-Left Lobe



Pearl PM1159: Couinaud's liver segments

The Couinaud classification is currently the most widely used system to describe functional liver anatomy.

* Based on the distribution of hepatic portal venous branches in the parenchyma

* Each segment has its own dual vascular inflow, biliary drainage and lymphatic drainage

Segment I corresponds to the gross anatomical caudate lobe and is considered as posterior segment.

Other segments:

Liver sections

Couinaud's Segments

Right anterior sections

Segments V,VIII

Right Posterior sections

Segments VI, VII

Left medial sections

Segment IV (quadrate lobe)

Left lateral sections

Segment II, III

questions.text: 6. Injury to which of the following structures can result in inability to extend the elbow, wrist and fingers?
questions.solution:
The inability to extend the elbow, wrist and fingers is seen in radial nerve injury. The structure marked as 3 is the radial nerve. It divides into the posterior interosseous nerve and the superficial radial nerve in the elbow.

1- Median Nerve

2- Ulnar nerve

4- Medial brachial cutaneous nerve



The radial nerve originates from the posterior cord of the brachial plexus. It mainly supplies the extensors of the elbow, wrist, and fingers. Branches of the radial nerve:

* In the axilla and the radial groove- It supplies the triceps muscles.

* Proximal to the lateral epicondyle- nerve to brachioradialis, extensor carpi radialis brevis

At the tip of the lateral epicondyle, the nerve divides into the superficial radial nerve and posterior interosseous nerve. Posterior interosseus nerve supplies the supinator, extensor digitorum, extensor digiti minimi, extensor carpi ulnaris, extensor pollicis longus, extensor indicis, abductor pollicis longus, and extensor pollicis brevis. 

Radial nerve injuries

Very high lesions like the lesions around the shoulder joint and axilla, crutch palsy, extension of the elbow, wrist, and hand are lost.

In high lesions like fractures of the humerus and prolonged tourniquet pressure, there is wrist drop, due to weakness of the radial extensors of the wrist, as well as inability to extend the metacarpophalangeal joints. It will also have a sensory loss on the skin over the anatomical snuff box.

Low lesions occur due to the fracture or dislocations of the elbow. The wrist and elbow extension is preserved but the patient cannot extend the metacarpophalangeal joint. There is also a radial extension of the wrist.

questions.text: 7. A final-year student is asked to assess the motor functions of a hemiplegic patient. He asks the patient to dorsiflex and invert both his feet. Which of the muscles marked in the given image performs both these movements?
questions.solution:
The tibialis anterior, which is marked as "4" in the image, produces both dorsiflexion and inversion of the foot. It is identified as the muscle that lies immediately adjacent to the tibia and is the most medial muscle of the anterior compartment of the leg. 

Tibialis anterior:

Origin - Lateral condyle and lateral surface of the tibial shaft, anterior surface of the interosseous membrane, the deep surface of the deep fascia, and the intermuscular septum between itself and extensor digitorum longus

Insertion - Medial and inferior surface of the medial cuneiform and adjoining part of the base of the first metatarsal.

Nerve supply - It is innervated by the deep fibular nerve, L4 and L5

Actions - Dorsiflexion and inversion of the foot. The muscle is most active during activities in which both these movements are combined, such as walking.



Other options:

Option A: According to electromyographic research, the fibularis tertius or peroneus tertius works with the extensor digitorum longus and tibialis anterior to produce dorsiflexion of the foot and along with fibularis brevis to produce eversion of the foot.

Option B: The lateral four toes are extended by the extensor digitorum longus. It is an ankle dorsiflexor that synergistically acts with the tibialis anterior, extensor hallucis longus, and fibularis tertius. It aids in tightening the plantar aponeurosis by working with the extensor hallucis longus.

Option C: Extensor hallucis longus dorsiflexes the foot and extends the great toe.

The dorsiflexors of the foot are shown in the image given below:



The plantar flexors of the foot are shown in the image given below:

questions.text: 8. Which of the following statements is false regarding the muscle marked "A" in the image given below?

choices.text: Originates from anterior superior iliac spine
The aponeurosis forms part of pes anserinus
Abducts and laterally rotates the thigh

questions.solution:
The structure marked "A" is sartorius. It is innervated by the Femoral nerve (L2, L3).

The sartorius muscle is known as the tailor muscle and is also the longest muscle in the body. The word "sartorius" is derived from the Latin word sartor, which translates to tailor, due to the way the individual will position one's leg while working.

Origin: Anterior superior iliac spine and the upper half of the notch below it.

Insertion: Into the superior aspect of the medial surface of the tibial shaft near the tibial tuberosity (joins aponeurosis of gracilis and semitendinosus to form pes anserinus).

Action: Flexion, abduction, and lateral rotation of the thigh; and flexion of the leg.

Innervation: By femoral nerve (L2, L3, and L4)

questions.text: 9. Which of the following post-mortem changes is a result of hydrolysis of lipids under warm and humid weather?
questions.solution:
Hydrolysis of lipids under warm and humid weather would result in adipocere formation, which is seen in image 4. 

Postmortem changes are classified on the basis of time:

* Immediate signs of death (at the time of somatic or clinical death):

* Insensibility and loss of voluntary power

* Cessation of respiration

* Cessation of circulation

* Early signs of death. It is seen in cellular death:

* Pallor and loss of elasticity of the skin

* Eye changes

* Primary flaccidity of muscles

* Algor mortis/Postmortem cooling

* Postmortem lividity/Suggillation

* Rigor mortis

* Late signs of death:

* Putrefaction

* Adipocere

* Mummification

Adipocere formation (Image 4) is a late sign of death. The transformation is brought about by the gradual hydrolysis and hydrogenation of pre-existing fats, including olein, into higher fatty acids. These higher fatty acids then join with calcium and ammonium ions to produce insoluble soaps, which since they are acidic, prevent putrefactive bacteria. The usual time for adipocere formation is between 3 to 6 months. Still, in countries like India, it is accelerated by the warm and humid weather, resulting in the beginning of adipocere formation as early as 4 to 5 days after death. 

Image 1. Marbling: It is seen when blood in the vessels is hemolyzed to sulfate-hemoglobin, which stains the vessel walls and the adjacent tissues, giving rise to a marbled appearance. The marbling of the skin begins at about 24 hours and becomes prominent  36–48 hours after death. It is a visible postmortem change that is characterized by linear branching patterns on skin that correspond to the course of superficial veins of the abdomen, shoulders, chest, and inguinal region.

Image 2. Cadaveric lividity: Postmortem hypostasis/Postmortem staining/Postmortem lividity/Livor mortis/Suggilation refers to bluish-purple or reddish-purple discoloration of the skin due to the collection of blood in most superficial layers of the dermis in the dependent parts of the body. Fixation of hypostasis occurs 6 – 12 hours after death and persists until putrefaction sets in.

Image 3. Mummification: It occurs in the absence of moisture in the air and continuous action of dry or warmed air. It is a process of dehydration or drying and shriveling of the cadaver that occurs from the evaporation of water. The natural appearances of the body and general facial features are preserved.

questions.text: 10. The given image is a dissected specimen of the posterior surface of the knee. What is the nature of the gait associated with damage to the structure marked in the image below?
questions.solution:
The structure marked is the common peroneal nerve. It is also called the common fibular nerve. Damage to it would result in a high stepping gait.

The common peroneal nerve descends down obliquely along the lateral side of the popliteal fossa, until the fibular head. It lies medial to the biceps femoris. The common peroneal nerve is a component of the sciatic nerve. In the posterior thigh, it supplies the short head of the biceps femoris. It curves around the neck of the fibula deep to the peroneus longus and divides into superficial and deep peroneal nerves.

* The superficial peroneal nerve innervates peroneus longus and peroneus brevis, which are the evertors of the foot, and to the skin over the dorsal area of the foot, except for the first webspace and lateral side of the little toe.

* The deep peroneal nerve innervates all muscles of the anterior compartment, which are the dorsiflexors of the foot, extensor digitorum brevis, first two dorsal interossei muscles, and skin between the great and second toes.







Common peroneal nerve is more prone to injury as it lies superficial at the level of the lateral aspect of the neck of the fibula. The clinical features of common peroneal nerve injury include the following:

* Foot drop (image below shows a foot drop in the right calf)

* Weakness or paralysis of ankle dorsiflexion, toe extension, and eversion

* A diminished sensation on the dorsum of the foot including the first dorsal web space

* Plantar flexion, inversion, and ankle reflex are preserved

Other options:

* Cautious gait is seen in persons with spinal TB; they will walk carefully with short steps to avoid pain resulting from movement.

* Wide-stepping gait is a broad-based unstable gait and is indicative of cerebellar dysfunction.

* Waddling gait is seen in developmental dysplasia of the hip and in proximal muscle weakness.



Pearl PM2281: Sciatic nerve divisions and supply

 

Sciatic nerve divisions and its supply 
Tibial division
Motor: 
semitendinous, semimembranous, long head biceps femoris, gastrocnemius popliteus, plantaris, soleus, tibialis posterior, flexor digitorum longus, flexor hallucis longus, abductor hallucis, flexor digit­orum brevis, flexor hallucis brevis, addcutor hallucis, foot interossei, abductor digiti minimi.
 
Sensory: 
none
Peroneal division
Motor:
short head of biceps femoris, foot interossei, Tibialis anterior, Extensor Hallucis longus, Extensor digitorum longus and Peroneus tertius, Peroneus Longus, Peroneus Brevis.
 
Sensory:
articular branch to knee joint
sural nerve branch 
- closeby structure: saphenous vein, achilles tendon
- anastomoses: br. of peroneal nerve
- termination as: lateral dorsal cutaneous nerve

questions.text: 11. Identify the muscle marked by the red arrow and its nerve supply.

choices.text: Mylohyoid; posterior division of mandibular nerve
Medial pterygoid; trunk of mandibular nerve
Lateral pterygoid; anterior division of mandibular nerve
Masseter; anterior division of mandibular nerve

questions.solution:
The marked muscle is the medial pterygoid muscle. It is innervated by the trunk of the mandibular nerve, which is a branch of the trigeminal nerve.

The medial pterygoid is a part of muscles of mastication. The muscle is identified by the lingual nerve, which runs on the surface of the medial pterygoid. The motor innervation for the muscles of mastication arises from the special visceral efferent column in the pons. 

The mandibular nerve is the largest branch of the trigeminal nerve and is a mixed nerve. It gives sensory innervation to the teeth and gums of the mandible, skin in the temporal region, part of the auricle, lower lip, the lower part of the face, anterior two-thirds of the tongue, and the oral cavity. The motor innervation is given to the muscles of mastication, tensor veli palatini, tensor tympani, mylohyoid and anterior belly of digastric.

The mandibular nerve, after supplying the medial pterygoid, divides into anterior and posterior divisions. 

Muscles of mastication

Medial pterygoid:

It has two heads. The deep head arises from the medial surface of the lateral pterygoid plate of the sphenoid bone and the superficial head arises from the maxillary tuberosity and the pyramidal process of the palatine bone. It is inserted into the posteroinferior part of the medial surface of the ramus and the angle of the mandible.

Its main actions are elevation of the mandible/ closing of the mouth, jaw protrusion, and side-to-side movement of the mandible. It is innervated by the trunk of the mandibular nerve.



Lateral pterygoid:

It has two heads. The upper head arises from the infratemporal surface and the infratemporal crest of the sphenoid bone. The lower head arises from the lateral surface of the lateral pterygoid plate. It is inserted into the pterygoid fovea, capsule, and the articular disc of the temporomandibular joint.

Its main actions are depression of the mandible/ opening of the mouth, jaw protrusion, and side-to-side movement of the mandible. It is innervated by the anterior division of the mandibular nerve.



Temporalis:

It arises from the temporal fossa up to the inferior temporal line and temporal fascia. It is inserted into the coronoid process and the anterior border of the mandibular ramus. It causes elevation of mandible/ closing of the mouth, jaw retraction, and side-to-side movement of the mandible. It is innervated by the anterior division of the mandibular nerve.



Masseter:

It arises from the zygomatic arch and from a thick aponeurosis from the maxillary process of the zygomatic bone. It is inserted into the angle and lower posterior half of the lateral surface of the mandibular ramus. Its main actions are elevation of the mandible/ closing of the mouth and jaw protrusion. It is innervated by the anterior division of the mandibular nerve.

questions.text: 12. The muscle marked as 'X' in the image below inserts at ________

choices.text: Lateral lip of the intertubercular sulcus
Medial lip of the intertubercular sulcus

questions.solution:
The muscle in the given image is teres major, its insertion is at the medial lip of the intertubercular sulcus.

The muscle in the image can be identified as teres major as it originates from the posterior surface of the inferior angle of the scapula. In relation to the infraspinatus muscle which arises from the posterior surface of the scapula, below the spine.

* It arises from the dorsal surface of the inferior scapular angle.

* The fibres of the muscle ascend laterally and get attached to the medial lip of the intertubercular sulcus in the humerus.

* It is supplied by the lower subscapular nerve which branches out from the posterior cord of the brachial plexus.



The floor of the intertubercular sulcus  - Site of insertion of Lattisimus Dorsi

The medial lip of the intertubercular sulcus - Site of insertion of Teres major

The lateral lip of the intertubercular sulcus - Site of insertion of pectoralis major

(remembered by “Lady between two majors”, i.e - Lattisimus Dorsi between pectoralis major and teres major)

Coracoid process of the scapula - site of insertion of pectoralis minor.

questions.text: 13. The given cadaveric cross-section is at which vertebral level?
questions.solution:
The given cadaveric cross-section is at the level of the T-10 vertebra.

T-10 vertebral landmarks for the viscera: Lower border of lungs, cardia of stomach, liver, spleen, and sometimes, upper border of the kidney are seen. Inferior vena cava, azygos vein, and descending thoracic aorta can also be seen.

Other options:

Option A: At the level of T-4 lies concavity of aortic arch, azygos vein into SVC, bifurcation of the pulmonary trunk, upper border of the heart and tracheal bifurcation.

Option B: At the level of L-1 lies the pylorus, transpyloric plane, hilum of the left kidney, the origin of renal arteries and superior mesenteric artery, neck of the pancreas and termination of the spinal cord.

Option C: At the level of T-7 lies the inferior angle of the scapula, lower border of the heart & central tendon of the diaphragm.

questions.text: 14. The cut section of the forearm is shown. Identify the type of joint labeled with a question mark.
questions.solution:
The given cross-section of the forearm with the visible tendon of the brachialis and biceps brachii shows the proximal radioulnar joint. The proximal radioulnar joint is an example of a pivot synovial joint.

The radius and ulna are united with each other by three joints: The proximal (superior) radioulnar joint, middle radioulnar joint, and distal (inferior) radioulnar joint. 

Proximal and distal radioulnar joints are uniaxial pivot joints (synovial) and are involved in pronation and supination movements of the forearm. A section at the level of the distal radioulnar joint can be identified by the presence of pronator quadratus, extensor retinaculum, ulnar nerve, medial nerve, etc.

The middle radioulnar joint is a fibrous joint (syndesmosis). The radius and ulna, in the middle, are connected by two syndesmoses, an oblique cord, and an interosseous membrane. A section at the level of the middle radioulnar joint can be identified by the presence of major muscles of the forearm like flexor digitorum profundus, flexor digitorum superficialis, extensor digitorum, and extensor carpi ulnaris.

 Based on the structure, joints are classified into three types:

* Fibrous joints

* Sutures- Skull

* Syndesmosis- bones are connected by the interosseus ligament. e.g. inferior tibiofibular joint

* Gomphosis- peg and socket type of joint. e.g. teeth

* Cartilaginous joints

* Primary cartilaginous joints or synchondrosis- These joints are united by hyaline cartilage and later they are replaced by bone. They are present in growth plates

* Secondary cartilaginous joints or symphysis- These joints are mainly united by fibrocartilage, and they persist throughout life. e.g. manubriosternal joint, intervertebral joints, and the symphysis pubis.

* Synovial joints

* Ball-and-socket or spheroidal joints

* Sellar or saddle joints

* Condylar or bicondylar joints

* Ellipsoid joints

* Hinge joints

* Pivot or trochoid joints

* Plane joints

The illustration below depicts the types of fibrous joints.



The illustration below depicts the types of synovial joints.



Pearl PM2388: Types of Synovial Joints

Classification of Synovial Joints
Type Articular surfaces Movement Examples
1. Plane Almost flat Minimal sliding movements Intercarpal, intermetacarpal, carpometacarpal (except first), intertarsal, intermetatarsal, tarsometatarsal, joints between articular processes of vertebrae, cricothyroid joint, cricoarytenoid joint, superior tibiofibular, interchondral joint (5-9 ribs), costovertebral, costotransverse, acromioclavicular, chondrosternal (except first) joints
2. Hinge Pulley shaped Uniaxial - flexion & extension Elbow, ankle, interphalangeal joints
3. Pivot Central pivot (peg) surrounded by osteoligamentous ring Uniaxial - rotation (supination and pronation) Superior and inferior radioulnar joints, median atlantoaxial joint
4. Condylar (bicondylar) 2 convex condyles articulate with concave or flat surfaces on the other side Biaxial - but predominantly one axis movement (flexion & extension) with limited rotation Knee joint, temporomandibular joint
5. Ellipsoid Oval convex surface fitting into an elliptical concavity Biaxial - flexion & extension, abduction & adduction, circumduction Radiocarpal (wrist), metacarpophalangeal joints
6. Saddle Each articular surface has a concave and convex region fitting the convex and concave regions of the other surface Biaxial - mainly 2 axis, flexion & extension,  abduction & adduction; very limited coupled axial rotation (conjunct rotation)  First carpometacarpal joint (of thumb), calcaneocuboid joints, incudomalleolar joint, sternoclavicular joint
7. Ball & Socket Globular head fitting into a cup-shaped socket Multiaxial - flexion & extension, abduction & adduction, circumduction, and rotation Shoulder, hip, talocalcaneonavicular, incudostapedial joint

Interphalangeal

Hinge

questions.text: 15. Which of the following structures is related to the area marked as A in the given image below?
questions.solution:
The cadaveric image shown is of the left lung. The arch of aorta is related to the area marked as A in the given image. 

The left lung is divided into superior and inferior lobes by the oblique fissure. The pulmonary root connects the medial surface of the lung to the heart and trachea. It is formed by structures that enter or leave the hilum. The left root is present inferior to the arch of the aorta.

The vertical sequence of structures at the left hilum from above to below is:

* Pulmonary artery

* Principal (hyparterial) bronchus, and

* Inferior pulmonary vein

The arrangement of the lung hilar structures from the anterior to posterior in the order is:

* Pulmonary vein

* Pulmonary artery

* Primary bronchus

* Bronchial artery

The cadaveric image given below shows the structures related to the hilum of the left lung.



The cadaveric image given below shows the structures related to the hilum of the right lung.



Pearl PM1162: Structures related to the mediastinal surface and hilum of the lungs

Right lung:

* Anterior to the hilum - superior vena cava and right brachiocephalic vein.

* Posterior to this groove-  azygous vein.

* Behind the hilum and pulmonary ligament- oesophagus.

* The cardiac impression - right auricle, right atrium and right ventricle

* Posteroinferiorly - inferior vena cava



Left lung:

* The cardiac impression - left ventricle and auricle and right ventricle

* Large groove that arches over the hilum and descends behind -  Arch of aorta and descending aorta.

* Arrow groove that ascends to the apex- left subclavian artery

* Superior to the aortic groove-  thoracic duct and esophagus.

* Anterior to subclavian groove - left brachiocephalic vein.

questions.text: 16. During the post-mortem examination of a patient who had a sudden cardiac death, significant hypertrophy in the apex of the heart was noted. Which of the following structures representing the chambers of the heart depict this apical enlargement?
questions.solution:
The chamber of the heart marked 3 depicting the left ventricle correctly represents the apex of the heart where hypertrophy was seen in the post-mortem finding.

The apex of the heart is the blunt round extremity of the heart formed by the left ventricle. The obtuse margin of this chamber mainly forms the left surface of the heart. It is directed anteroinferiorly and to the left side. It is overlapped by the left lung and the pleura. The apex is commonly located behind the fifth left intercostal space, near or medial to the midclavicular line. It also forms the inferior and diaphragmatic surface of the heart. 

Other options:

Option A: Arrow 4 depicts the left atrium. It forms the cardiac base of the heart, a quadrilateral area directed posteriorly.

Option B: Arrow 2 depicts the right ventricle, the inferior border of the heart. 

Option D: Arrow 1 depicts the right atrium. It is the right surface of the heart, also forming the anterior, and sternocostal boundaries. 

A specimen of the heart with the various parts labeled is given below:

questions.text: 17. A patient who presented with a stab injury over the anterior abdominal wall passes away. While performing an autopsy on the patient, as you are making the incision over the abdomen, you see the muscle marked X in close proximity to the linea alba as shown in the image. In your injury documentation, you would identify the marked structure X to be _____________.
questions.solution:
The marked structure is the internal oblique muscle. It can be identified by their fibres which pass obliquely upwards and are attached to the ribs.

Internal Oblique muscle: Its fibres begin at the anterior 2/3 of the iliac crest and the lateral half of the inguinal ligament. The muscle fibres run from these points superomedially (up and towards the midline) to the muscle's insertions on the inferior borders of the 10th through 12th ribs and the linea alba. 

The anterior abdominal wall comprises 4 muscles:

* External oblique

* Internal oblique

* Transversus abdominis

* Rectus abdominis

Action

Muscles involved

Forward flexion of trunk (Lumbar spine)

Rectus Abdominis and bilateral IO and EO

Lateral flexion of  the trunk

Ipsilateral IO and EO
Rotation of trunk

Ipsilateral IO and contralateral EO

Tensing the Linea alba

Pyramidalis

Pulling the testes towards the superficial inguinal ring

Cremaster

questions.text: 18. What is false regarding the structure marked by the red arrow in the given image of the gluteal region?

choices.text: Causes lateral rotation of the thigh in extension
Causes abduction of the thigh in flexion
Sciatic nerve lies closely related to the muscle

questions.solution:
The structure marked is the piriformis muscle.

The muscle has its origin from the following structures.

* The anterior surface of the sacrum

* The posterior inferior iliac spine

* The capsule of the sacroiliac joint

* Sacrotuberous ligament

It passes outside the pelvis through the greater sciatic foramen.

It inserts into the greater trochanter of the femur. The muscle forms the posterolateral wall of the pelvic cavity. The sciatic nerve is closely related to the muscle and passes below it.

Action: Lateral rotation of the thigh in extension and abduction of the thigh in the flexed position.

Clinical note: Piriformis syndrome is a clinical condition characterized by the compression of the sciatic nerve by the piriformis muscle.



Pearl PM1242: Structures Passing Through the Sciatic Foramens

Structures passing through the greater sciatic foramen

The piriformis is the key muscle of this region. It emerges from the pelvis, and fills the foramen almost completely.

Structures passing above the piriformis

* Superior gluteal nerve

* Superior gluteal vessels

Structures passing below the piriformis

* Inferior gluteal nerve         

* Inferior gluteal vessels

* Sciatic nerve                                              

* Posterior cutaneous nerve of thigh

* Nerve to quadratus femoris                  

* Pudendal nerve

* Internal pudendal vessels                                  

* Nerve to obturator internus

Note: The last three structures, after a short course in the gluteal region, enter the lesser sciatic foramen, where the pudendal nerve and internal pudendal vessels run in the pudendal canal.

Structures passing through the lesser sciatic foramen

* Tendon of obturator internus

* Pudendal nerve

* Internal pudendal vessels

* Nerve to obturator internus



Pearl PM2280: Various muscles of the gluteal region and their innervation

Muscles

Innervation

Gluteus maximus

 Inferior gluteal nerve

Gluteus medius and minimus

 Superior gluteal nerve

Pyriformis

 Nerve to pyriformis

Obturator internus, Gemellus superior

 Nerve to obturator internus

Quadratus femoris, Gemellus inferior

 Nerve to quadratus femoris

questions.text: 19. A male patient is brought to the emergency room with a gunshot injury to his knee. On surgical exploration, you see damage to the structure marked in the image given below. Identify the correct statement regarding the structure marked.

choices.text: The marked structure is the femoral artery.
It is the continuation of the profunda femoris artery.
The tibial nerve crosses medial to lateral to this artery.
It divides into the anterior and posterior tibial artery.

questions.solution:
The structure marked in the above image is the popliteal artery in the popliteal fossa. It divides into the anterior and posterior tibial arteries.

The popliteal artery is a continuation of the femoral artery and gives anterior and posterior tibial artery branches. 

Contents of the popliteal fossa:

* Popliteal artery and its branches

* Popliteal vein and its tributaries

* Tibial nerve

* Common fibular/ peroneal nerve

* Short saphenous vein

* Posterior femoral cutaneous nerve

* Articular branch of the obturator nerve

* Medial and lateral sural cutaneous nerve

* Lymph nodes

* Fat

* Bursae

The illustration given below shows the boundaries and contents of the popliteal fossa.

questions.text: 20. A specimen of the posterior surface of the larynx is kept in an anatomy practical exam and a structure is marked with red. What would be the action of the structure?
questions.solution:
The above image shows the posterior view of the larynx and the marked muscle is the posterior cricoarytenoid. Its action is to abduct the vocal cords and open the glottis. The posterior cricoarytenoid muscle is identified by its origin from the posterior surface of the cricoid. 

The posterior cricoarytenoid muscle arises from the posterior surface of the cricoid lamina and is attached to the upper and posterior surfaces of the muscular processes of the ipsilateral arytenoids. It is innervated by a branch of the recurrent laryngeal nerve. They are active in the production of unvoiced sounds.



The image below shows the intrinsic muscles of the larynx.



Pearl PM1978: Muscles of larynx

Remember 2 exceptions:

* All muscles are adductors, except PCA (an abductor)

* All muscles are supplied by the recurrent laryngeal nerve, except cricothyroid (superior laryngeal nerve)

Action
Muscle
Opening of the inlet of larynx
Thyroepiglotticus
Closing of the inlet of larynx
Aryepiglotticus, Interarytenoids
Abductor of vocal cords
Posterior cricoarytenoid
Adductor of vocal cords
Lateral cricoarytenoid
Tensor of vocal cords
Cricothyroid
Relaxer of vocal cord
Thyroarytenoid
Modulator of larynx
Vocalis


Safety muscle of larynx: Posterior cricoarytenoid

Safety muscle of tongue: Genioglossus

The muscle of whispering: Lateral cricoarytenoid

Vocalis is known as the modulator of larynx because, the anterior part of the vocalis muscle can tense the vocal cord, and its posterior part can relax the vocal cord.

Pearl PM0927: Cartilages of Larynx



Unpaired Cartilages
Paired Cartilages
  • Thyroid
  • Cricoid
  • Epiglottis
  • Arytenoid
  • Corniculate
  • Cuneiform


 

Hyaline
Fibroelastic
  • Thyroid
  • Cricoid
  • Arytenoids
  • Epiglottis

  • Cuneiform
